turns.speaker: THERESA
turns.text: Let's just go, Marsha.

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: No, we have to get this story.

turns.speaker: THERESA
turns.text: I thought you'd be happy to leave.

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: Why won't he talk to women?

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: My name's Jerry Woolridge.

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: Nice to meet you. I'm Marsha Dwiggins and this is Theresa Evans. She's here to take the pictures.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Y'all have a seat. Is this all of you?

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: I think there must have been a little mix up. I told your sponsor or teacher or whatever he is, there couldn't be any pictures. It's s'posed to be just a little story or article or something, isn't that right?

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: Well, yeah, it's for the school newspaper. But it has pictures. I mean it's a regular paper, you know.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Karl's real sensitive about having his picture made. He wouldn't even be on the bulletin board for the Easter Collage.  Melvin, would you get me a good hot cup with two sugar substitutes? You girls want some coffee?

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: No thank you.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: The other thing is I told your boss on the phone to send a man. Karl won't talk to women.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: I don't know what to tell you. I'm sorry. I made myself pretty clear I thought. He probably got busy and wasn't thinking. I know how that is. I used to teach shop and eighth grade science.

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: Well, what do we do? We drove all the way out here.

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: Can't you talk to him? Maybe talk him into it. I'm a real good interviewer. Just get me in the room with him.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Melvin, go get Karl and take him down to the old classroom.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: You see, Karl, growing up, only knew that sex was wrong and that people who did it should be killed for it. He couldn't really read but, well, neither could his mother. But, his father made sure that his mother knew what the Bible said. And she made sure Karl knew. You know he slept in a hole in the ground under a toolshed, right?

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: I knew he slept in a toolshed.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: His mother told him that he was their punishment. Hers and his father's; from God, for having sex--

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: Before they were married?

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: I don't think so. Just period, I think. She told him... God gave them the ugliest creation he could think of. Karl has an entire book -- a notebook. On every page it says "Franklin Chapter 1 Verse number 1." He wrote that a few years ago after he'd learned to write. His father's name was Franklin.

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: That's really strange. What does it mean?

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: One of his Daddy's Bible lessons I imagine. Y'all pull up a chair. I'll go out and talk to him.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: But, here's the thing. He'll only talk to you. He doesn't want you to ask him anything. And you shouldn't stare at him.

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: How am I going to conduct an interview if I can't ask him any questions?

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: It's the best you're gonna get. I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: Can I ask you a question? If he's so troubled, why are you letting him out? What if he does it again? It happens all the time.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: He's free. His time's up. That's the rules. He's been treated and reevaluated. He doesn't show any signs any more.

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: Signs?

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Homicidal signs. Oh, we're gonna change the light in here for Karl. I hope you can see to write.

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: Is he leaving right this minute?

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: We've got some paperwork to take care of. Pretty soon. Don't worry, you won't run into him in the parking lot.

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: I didn't mean that.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: I hope the best for you, Miss Dwiggins, with your school and your paper and all.

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: Where will he go?

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Wherever he wants to. I think he's going back to Millsburg where he's from. It's just about twenty miles from here.

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: Will he be supervised?

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: As much as anybody else is, I guess. Y'all have a good rest of the day now.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Also, Melinda, please don't tell anybody at the store that Albert was here tonight, okay.

turns.speaker: MELINDA
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Well, a lot of people in town talk and spread cruel rumors. Unfortunately, I have to keep certain parts of my life private.

turns.speaker: MELINDA
turns.text: You mean about y'all bein' together in "that" way?

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MELINDA
turns.text: I think everybody at the store knows that already. They always talk about it. Maureen Ledbetter told a awful story about why you ain't allowed over at the First Baptist Church no more.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: It's coming along. At the rate he's going, he'll have a story finished by the end of the summer.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Wonderful. When your next book is published, maybe you could come into the store and do a signing. I'm sure we could get a lot of people to show up.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: What!

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Perhaps I should rephrase the question. What I mean to say is, are you married or seriously involved with a significant other?

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: No! At least I don't think I am!

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Good. Then may I have the honor of extending an invitation to you?

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: An invitation?

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: And what's the occasion of this celebration?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: It's my birthday.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: And how many people will be attending this birthday party?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I wouldn't actually call it a party. It's more along the lines of a dinner in celebration of my birthday.  The guest list is quite restricted. So far, there's Mr. Benjamin and myself. If you accept, that would make three of us.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Ah-hah, I see. A cozy dinner. But aren't threesomes a little awkward? How does the phrase go--

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Three's a crowd. Yes, I'm aware of that. But I have to keep an eye on Mr. Benjamin wherever he goes. To make sure he doesn't get himself into trouble.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: And what are you, his chaperone?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Actually, I'm his father.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Like me, too.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: I once read somewhere that one quarter of all the people in the United States have at least one relative who has lived in Brooklyn at one time or another.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: No wonder it's such a screwed-up place.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Will that be cash or charge?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Better make it charge.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: I thought I recognized you. You're Paul Benjamin the writer, aren't you?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I confess.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: I keep waiting for the next novel to come out. Anything in the works?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: So your mother grew up in Shanghai?

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Until she was twelve. She moved here in 'forty-nine.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And your father? Is he from New York?

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Muncie, Indiana. He and my mother met as students. But I'm from Brooklyn. My sisters and I were all born and bred right here.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Just like me.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And the bookstore? Have you been working there long?

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: It's just a summer job. Something to help pay the bills while I finish my dissertation.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Your dissertation? What subject do you study?

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: American literature. What else?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What else. Of course, what else? And what are you writing about for your thesis?

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Visions of Utopia in Nineteenth-Century American Fiction.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Wow. You don't fool around, do you?

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Of course I fool around. But not so much when it comes to my work, it's true.  Have you ever read Pierre, or the Ambiguities?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Melville, huh?  It's been a while.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: That's the subject of my last chapter.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Not an easy book.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Which explains why this hasn't been the easiest summer of my life.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Jesus, what happened to you?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It looks worse than it is. I'm okay.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'll tell you all about it...  ... but not here.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: It's been a while. I thought maybe you'd be in touch.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah, well, I've sort of been out of commission.  How's Melville?

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Almost done. A week or ten days, and I'll be there.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I finished my story. I thought you might want to take a look at it.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: I'd love to.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Good. I hope you like it. It was a long time in coming.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: I get off for lunch in ten minutes. Can I treat you to a hamburger?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Uh ... actually, it might be better if you read the story first. Call me when you're finished, okay?

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Okay. I'll read it tonight and call you tomorrow.  It doesn't seem to be too long.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Forty-one pages.

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: What'll it be, Auggie?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Uh...  My friend over here would like a corned beef on rye and a ginger ale.

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: And what about for you?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: What about for you?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: For me?  I'll have the same thing.

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: Do me a favor, will you?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: What's that, Sol?

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: Next time, when you want two corned beef sandwiches, say, "Two corned beef sandwiches." When you want two ginger ales, say, "Two ginger ales."

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: What's the difference?

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: It's simpler, that's what. It makes things go faster.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Uh, sure, Sol. Anything you say. Instead of saying, "One corned beef sandwich," and then, "Another corned beef sandwich," I'll say, "Two corned beef sandwiches."

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: Thanks. I knew you'd understand.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Hey, Auggie. How's it going?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Hey, man. Good to see you. What'll it be today?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Two tins of Schimmelpennincks. And throw in a lighter while you're at it.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: The boys and I were just having a philosophical discussion about women and cigars. Some interesting connections there, don't you think?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Definitely.  I suppose it all goes back to Queen Elizabeth.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: The Queen of England?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Not Elizabeth the Second, Elizabeth the First.  Did you ever hear of Sir Walter Raleigh?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Seven eighty-five out of twenty.  Take care of yourself now, and don't do anything I wouldn't do.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I wouldn't think of it.  See you around, fellas.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Are you closed?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: You run out of Schimmelpennincks?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Do you think I could buy some before you leave?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: No problem. It's not as though I'm rushing off to the opera or anything.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Looks like someone forgot a camera.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Yeah, I did.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's yours?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: It's mine all right. I've owned that little sucker for a long time.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I didn't know you took pictures.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: I guess you could call it a hobby. It doesn't take me more than about five minutes a day to do it, but I do it every day. Rain or shine, sleet or snow. Sort of like the postman.  Sometimes it feels like my hobby is my real job, and my job is just a way to support my hobby.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: So you're not just some guy who pushes coins across a counter.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: That's what people see, but that ain't necessarily what I am.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: How'd you get started?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Taking pictures?  It's a long story. I'd need two or three drinks to get through that one.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: A photographer ...

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Well, let's not exaggerate. I take pictures. You line up what you want in the viewfinder and click the shutter. No need to mess around with all that artisto crap.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'd like to see your pictures some day.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: It can be arranged. Seeing as how I've read your books. I don't see why I shouldn't share my pictures with you.  It would be an honor.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: They're all the same.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: That's right. More than four thousand pictures of the same place. The corner of 3rd Street and Seventh Avenue at eight o'clock in the morning. Four thousand straight days in all kinds of weather.  That's why I can never take a vacation. I've got to be in my spot every morning. Every morning in the same spot at the same time.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I've never seen anything like it.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: It's my project. What you'd call my life's work.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Amazing.  I'm not sure I get it, though. I mean, how did you ever come up with the idea to do this ... this project?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: I don't know, it just came to me. It's my corner, after all. It's just one little part of the world, but things happen there, too, just like everywhere else. It's a record of my little spot.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's kind of overwhelming.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: You'll never get it if you don't slow down, my friend.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: I mean, you're going too fast. You're hardly even looking at the pictures.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: But they're all the same.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: They're all the same, but each one is different from every other one. You've got your bright mornings and your dark mornings. You've got your summer light and your autumn light. You've got your weekdays and your weekends. You've got your people in overcoats and galoshes, and you've got your people in shorts and T-shirts. Sometimes the same people, sometimes different ones. And sometimes the different ones become the same, and the same ones disappear. The earth revolves around the sun, and every day the light from the sun hits the earth at a different angle.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Slow down, huh?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Yeah, that's what I'd recommend. You know how it is. Tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow, time creeps on its petty pace.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Yeah. There she is. She's in quite a few from that year. She must have been on her way to work.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's Ellen. Look at her. Look at my sweet darling.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Hey, man, good to see you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: This is April Lee, Auggie. April, say hello to Auggie Wren.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: So, what brings you to a dive like this?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's his birthday so we decided to whoop it up a little.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: How old, kid?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Hey, Auggie, I've just been thinking. You wouldn't need some help around the store, would you? Some summer help while Vinnie's gone?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Help? Hmm. It's possible. What did you have in mind?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'm thinking about the kid. I'm sure he'd do a good job for you.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Hey, kid. You interested in a job? I just got word from your employment agency that you're looking for a position in retail sales.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: The kid's sorry, Auggie.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Yeah, well, I'm sorry too.  It took me three years to save up those five thousand bucks, and now I'm broke. I can't hardly pay for this beer. Not to speak of having my credibility destroyed. Do you understand what I'm saying? My credibility. So yeah, I'm sorry, too. About as sorry as I've ever been in my whole fucking life.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: He's got something to tell you, Auggie.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: If he's got something to tell me, why don't he tell it to me himself?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Don't be an ass, Auggie. He's trying to make it up to you, can't you see that?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: He's crazy.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No, he's not. You are.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: You're right. I just wasn't sure you knew.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's written all over you like a neon sign. Now say something nice to Rashid to make him feel better.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Fuck you, kid.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It could have been worse. If the cops hadn't come, I might not be standing here now.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Cops? You mean they nabbed those cruds?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No. The ... uh ... the Bobbsey Twins lit out when they heard the sirens. But at least they stopped playing that marimba duet on my skull.  Assaultus interruptus.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Fuckus my assus. They did some number on you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: For once in my life I managed to keep my mouth shut. There's something to be said for that, I suppose.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You haven't heard from Rashid, have you?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Not a peep.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I spoke to his aunt a couple of days ago, but she hasn't heard from him either. It's beginning to get a little scary.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: That could be a good sign, though. It could mean that he got away.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Or didn't.  There's no way of knowing, is there?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: So what did he say when he called?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Nothing much. He said his socks and underpants were dirty, and would we mind driving up with his things.  Fucking kids, huh? They take you for granted every time.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Nice machine, Auggie. Where'd you find it?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: It's Tommy's. The sucker owed me a favor.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's not a long drive. An hour, an hour and a half. We'll be back in time for dinner.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: We'd better be. I haven't spent a night out of Brooklyn in fourteen years, and I'm not about to break my record now. Besides, I've got to be on my corner at eight sharp tomorrow morning.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Hey, man, how's it going?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Hi, Auggie.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Two, right?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Uh, better make it one.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: You usually get two.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah, I know, but I'm trying to cut down.  Somebody's worried about my health.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Ah-hah.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Fine.  Or it was until a couple of days ago. A guy from The New York Times called and asked me to write a Christmas story. They want to publish it on Christmas Day.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: That's a feather in your cap, man. The paper of record.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah, great. The problem is, I have four days to come up with something, and I don't have a single idea.  You know anything about Christmas stories?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Christmas stories? Sure, I know a ton of 'em.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Anything good?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Good? Of course. Are you kidding?  I'll tell you what. Buy me lunch, my friend, and I'll tell you the best Christmas story you ever heard. How's that? And I guarantee every word of it is true.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It doesn't have to be true. It just has to be good.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Take over the register while I'm gone, okay, Jimmy?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I have to pee.  If the waiter comes, order me a corned beef on rye and a ginger ale, okay?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: You got it.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: So. Are we ready?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Ready. Any time you are.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'm all ears.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Okay.  You remember how you once asked me how I started taking pictures? Well, this is the story of how I got my first camera. As a matter of fact, it's the only camera I've ever had. Are you following me so far?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Every word.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Okay.  So this is the story of how it happened.  Okay.  It was the summer of 'seventy-six, back when I first started working for Vinnie. The summer of the bicentennial.  A kid came in one morning and started stealing things from the store. He's standing by the rack of paperbacks near the front window stuffing skin magazines under his shirt. It was crowded around the counter just then, so I didn't see him at first....

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Did you ever go back to see her?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Once, about three or four months later. I felt so bad about stealing the camera, I hadn't even used it yet. I finally made up my mind to return it, but Granny Ethel wasn't there anymore. Someone else had moved into the apartment, and he couldn't tell me where she was.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: She probably died.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Yeah, probably.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Which means that she spent her last Christmas with you.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: I guess so. I never thought of it that way.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It was a good deed, Auggie. It was a nice thing you did for her.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: I lied to her, and then I stole from her. I don't see how you can call that a good deed.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You made her happy. And the camera was stolen anyway. It's not as if the person you took it from really owned it.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Anything for art, eh, Paul?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I wouldn't say that. But at least you've put the camera to good use.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: And now you've got your Christmas story, don't you?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yes, I suppose I do.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I mean, it's a good story.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Shit. If you can't share your secrets with your friends, what kind of friend are you?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Exactly. Life just wouldn't be worth living, would it?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Christ, Ruby, it's been so long. I figured you were dead.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Eighteen and a half years.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Is that all? I thought it was about three hundred.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: You're looking good, Auggie.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: No I'm not. I look like shit. And so do you, Ruby. You look just awful.  What's with the patch, anyway? What'd you do with that old blue marble -- hock it for a bottle of gin?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I don't want to talk about it.  If you really want to know. I lost it. And I'm not sorry I did. That eye was cursed, Auggie, and it never gave me nothing but grief.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: And you think it looks better to go around dressed up like Captain Hook?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: You always were a son-of-a-bitch, weren't you? A little weasel with a quick, dirty mouth.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: At least I've stayed true to myself. Which is more than I can say about some people.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I've got something to talk to you about, and the least you can do is listen. You owe me that much. I drove all the way from Pittsburgh to see you, and I'm not going until you've heard me out.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Talk away, lady of my dreams. I'm all ears.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: This is private, Auggie. Just between you and I.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: You heard her, pipsqueak. The lady and I have private business to discuss. Go outside and stand in front of the door. If anyone tries to come in, tell 'em we're closed. You got that?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: All right, sugar, what's on your mind?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Don't look at me like that. Auggie. It gives me the creeps.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Like what you're doing. I'm not going to eat you up.  I need your help, and if you keep staring at me like that. I might start screaming.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Help, huh? And I don't suppose this help has anything to do with money, does it?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Don't rush me, okay? You're jumping to conclusions before I've even said anything.  And besides, it's not for me.  It's for our daughter.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Our daughter? Is that what you said? Our daughter? I mean, you might have a daughter, but I sure as hell don't. And even if I did -- which I don't -- she wouldn't be our daughter.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Her name is Felicity, and she just turned eighteen.  She ran away from Pittsburgh last year, and now she's living in some shit-hole here in Brooklyn with a guy named Chico. Strung out on crack, four months pregnant.  I can't bear to think about that baby. Our grandchild, Auggie. Just think of it. Our grandchild.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Stop it, already. Just stop all this crap right now.  Was that your idea to call her Felicity?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: It means "happiness."

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: I know what it means. That still don't make it a good name.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I don't know who else to turn to, Auggie.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: You've suckered me before, darling, remember? Why should I believe you now?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Why would I lie to you, Auggie? You think it was easy to come here and walk into this place? Why would I do it if I didn't have to?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: That's what you told me when I shoplifted that necklace for you. You remember, baby, don't you? The judge gave me a choice: either go to the can or enlist. So, instead of going to college, I wind up in the navy for four years, I watch men lose their arms and legs, I nearly get my head blown off, and you, sweet Ruby McNutt, you run off and marry that asshole, Bill.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: You didn't write to me for more than a year. What was I supposed to think?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Yeah, well, I lost my pen. By the time I got a new one, I was clean out of paper.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: It was over with Bill before you ever came home. Maybe you don't remember it now, but you were pretty hot to see me back then.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: You weren't so lukewarm yourself. At least at first.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: It fizzled, baby. That's the way it goes. But we had our times, didn't we? It wasn't all bad.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: A couple of moments, I'll grant you that. A second or two snatched from the jaws of eternity.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: And that's how Felicity came into the picture. During one of those two seconds.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: You're conning me, sweetheart. I ain't responsible for no baby.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Then why do you think I married Frank? I was already pregnant, and I didn't have much time. Say what you like, but at least he gave my kid a name.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Good old Frank. And how is fat Mr. Grease Monkey these days?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Who the hell knows?  He dropped out of sight fifteen years ago.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Fifteen years ago?  It won't wash, pumpkin. No mother waits fifteen years to tell a man he's a father. I wasn't born yesterday, you know.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I thought I could handle it. I didn't want to bug you. I thought I could handle it on my own, but I couldn't. She's in real bad, Auggie.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Nice try, old girl. I'd like to help you out. You know, for old time's sake. But all my spare cash is tied up in a business venture, and I haven't collected my profits yet. Too bad. You caught me at the wrong time.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: You're a cold-hearted bastard, aren't you? How'd you ever get so mean, Auggie?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: I know you think I'm lying to you, but I'm not. Every word I told you is the God's honest truth.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Get in, Auggie. I've got something to show you.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: You don't give up, do you?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Just get in and shut up. I'm not asking you to do anything. I just need you to come with me.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Where to?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Dammit, Auggie, don't ask so many questions. Just get in the car.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I told her she was going to meet her father.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: You what?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: It was the only way, Auggie. Otherwise, she wasn't going to let me see her.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: I think you'd better stop the car and let me out.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Relax, okay? You don't have to do anything. Just go in there and pretend. It won't kill you to do a little favor like that. Besides, you might even learn something.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Yeah, like what?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: That I wasn't bullshitting you, sweetheart. At least you'll know I've been telling the truth.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Look, I'm not saying you don't have a daughter. It's just that she's not my daughter.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Wait till you see her, Auggie.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: And what's that supposed to mean?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: She looks just like you.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Cut it out. Just cut it out, okay? It's starting to get on my nerves.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: When I told her I was going to bring her father, she kind of melted. It's the first time Felicity's talked nice to me since she left home. She's dying to meet you, Auggie.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Jesus Christ. This is all I need.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: You told me you wanted to meet him. Well,here he is.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: So you're just going to give up and go home?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I don't have much choice, do I? It's pretty clear she doesn't want me around.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Still, you can't just write her off.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Yeah? And what else am I supposed to do? There's no baby anymore, and if she wants to throw away her life, that's her business.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: She's just a kid. There's time for more babies later. After she grows up.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Dream on, Auggie. She'll be lucky to make it to her nineteenth birthday.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Not if you got her into one of those rehab programs.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I'd never be able to talk her into it. And even if I could, those things cost money. And that's just what I don't have. I'm flat out dead broke.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: No you're not.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Are you calling me a liar? I'm telling you I'm broke. I don't even have insurance on my goddamned car.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Remember that business venture I was telling you about? Well, my tugboat came in. I'm flush.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Bully for you.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: No, bully for you.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Why don't you open it and find out?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Jesus God, Auggie. There's money in here.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Five thousand bucks.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: And you're giving it to me?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: It's all yours, baby.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: For keeps?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: For keeps.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I can't believe it. Oh God, I can't believe it.  You're an angel, Auggie. An angel from heaven.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Fuck this angel shit. Just take the dough, Ruby. But no bawling, okay? I can't stand people who blubber.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I'm sorry, baby. I can't help it.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: There's just one thing I want to know.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Anything, Auggie. Just name it.

turns.speaker: VINNIE
turns.text: Okay. I think everything's set.  You've got the number for Cape Cod, right? Just in case something goes wrong.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: No problem, Vinnie. Everything's under control.  I could run this store in my sleep.

turns.speaker: VINNIE
turns.text: How long you been working for me, Auggie?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: I don't know. Thirteen, fourteen years. Something like that.

turns.speaker: VINNIE
turns.text: It's pretty crazy, don't you think? I mean, a smart guy like you. What do you want to hang on to a dead-end job like this for?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: I don't know.  Maybe because I love you so much, boss.

turns.speaker: VINNIE
turns.text: Shit. You should have been married to someone by now. You know, settled down somewhere with a kid or two, a nice steady job.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: I almost got married once.

turns.speaker: VINNIE
turns.text: Yeah, I know. To that girl who moved to Pittsburgh.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Ruby McNutt. My one true love.

turns.speaker: VINNIE
turns.text: Sounds like another one of your stories to me.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: She upped and married some other cat after I joined the navy. By the time I got my discharge, though, she was divorced. Her husband poked out her eye in a domestic quarrel.

turns.speaker: VINNIE
turns.text: Lovely.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: She made a play for me after I got back, but her glass eye kept interfering with my concentration. Every time we got into a clinch, I'd start thinking about that hole in her head, that empty socket with the glass eye in it. An eye that couldn't see, an eye that couldn't shed any tears. The minute I started thinking about it, Mr. Johnson would get all soft and small. And I can't see getting married if Mr. Johnson isn't going to be in tiptop shape.

turns.speaker: VINNIE
turns.text: You don't take anything seriously, do you?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: I try not to, anyway. It's better for your health. I mean, look at you, Vincent. You're the guy with the wife and three kids and the ranch house on Long Island. You're the guy with the white shoes and the white Caddy and the white shag carpet. But you've had two heart attacks, and I'm still waiting for my first.

turns.speaker: VINNIE
turns.text: I should stop smoking these damn things is what I should do. The fuckers are going to kill me one day.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Enjoy it while you can, Vin. Pretty soon, they're going to legislate us out of business anyway.

turns.speaker: VINNIE
turns.text: They catch you smoking tobacco, they'll stand you up against a wall and shoot you.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Tobacco today, sex tomorrow. In three or four years, it'll probably be against the law to smile at strangers.

turns.speaker: VINNIE
turns.text: Speaking of which, are you still going ahead with that deal on the Montecristos?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: It's all set. My guy in Miami said he'd have them within the next few weeks.  Are you sure you don't want to go in with me? Five thousand dollars outlay, a guaranteed ten-thousand-dollar return. A consortium of Court Street lawyers and judges. They're just drooling to get their lips around some genuine Cuban cigars.

turns.speaker: VINNIE
turns.text: No thanks. I don't care what you do, but just make sure you don't get caught, okay? The last I heard, it was still illegal to sell Cuban cigars in this country.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: It's the law that's buying. That's what's so beautiful about it. I mean, when was the last time you heard of a judge sending himself to jail?

turns.speaker: VINNIE
turns.text: Suit yourself. But don't keep the boxes around here long.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: They come in, they go out. I've got it planned to the last detail.

turns.speaker: VINNIE
turns.text: I've got to get moving. Terry will bust my chops if I'm late. See you in September, Auggie.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Okay, my man. Love to the wife and kids, et cetera, et cetera. Drop me a postcard if you can remember the address.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Seventeen.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Seventeen? I remember when I was seventeen. Christ, I was one little whacked-out son-of-a-bitch when I was seventeen. Is that what you are, son? One little whacked-out crazy fella?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Definitely. I'd say you've hit the nail on the head.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Good. Keep it up, and maybe one day you'll grow up and become a great man like me.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: A job?  I definitely wouldn't turn down a job.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Come around to the cigar store tomorrow morning at ten o'clock and we'll talk about it, okay? We'll see what we can work out.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Ten o'clock tomorrow morning. I'll be there.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: I'll be back in about an hour. Watch the register while I'm gone, okay?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Sure thing. See you later.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: A little. Not much.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: This way, gentlemen. Let's retire to my office, shall we?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: It's for you.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: For me? And what am I supposed to do with a paper bag?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Open it.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: What is this, some kind of joke?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: No, it's five thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Shit. I don't want your money, you little twerp.  It's probably stolen anyway.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: What do you care where it comes from? It's yours.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: And why the hell would you give me money?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: So I can get my job back.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Your job? You've got five thousand bucks. What do you want a piece-of-shit job like that for?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: To look at the dirty magazines. I can see all the naked women I want, and it doesn't cost me a cent.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: You're a dumb, whacked-out little fuck, do you know that?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Come on, come on, you yellow belly. The whole thing. First name and last name.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: What difference does it make?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: How'd you do out there, Jimmy?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Good, Auggie. Real good.  All finished.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: It'll never be finished.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: That's how it is with sidewalks. People come, people go, and they all drop shit on the ground. As soon as you clean up one spot and move on to the next, the first spot is dirty again.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I just do what you tell me, Auggie. You tell me to sweep, so I sweep.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Sure, Auggie, I got it.  The store's closed.  And when do I tell them it's open?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: When I tell you it's open. It's open when I tell you it's open!

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Okay, Auggie, I got it. You don't have to yell.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: ... If it happens, it happens. If it doesn't, it doesn't. Do you understand what I'm saying? You never know what's going to happen next, and the moment you think you know, that's the moment you don't know a goddamn thing. That's what we call a paradox. Are you following me?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Sure, Auggie. I follow. When you don't know nothing, it's like paradise. I know what that is. It's after you're dead and you go up to heaven and sit with the angels.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Jesus, man, you're one fucking mess.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Does it hurt?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Of course it hurts. What does it look like?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I thought maybe he was pretending.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: They don't come cheap, son. These little honeys are works of art. Rolled by hand in a tropical climate, most likely by an eighteen year old girl in a thin cotton dress with no underwear on. Little beads of sweat forming in her naked cleavage. The smooth, delicate fingers nimbly turning out one masterpiece after another...

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: And how much are these?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Seventy-eight dollars. The girl who rolled these was probably wearing panties.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: And these?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Fifty-six.  That girl had on a corset.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: And these?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Forty-four. They're on special this week from the Canary Islands. A real bargain.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: I think I'll take them.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: A good choice. You wouldn't want to celebrate the birth of your firstborn with a box of stinkers, would you? Remember to keep them in the refrigerator until you hand them out.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: The refrigerator?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: It'll keep them fresh. If they get too dry, they'll break. And you don't want that to happen, do you?  Tobacco is a plant, and it needs the same loving care you'd give an orchid.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: Thanks for the tip.

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Any time. And congratulations to you and your wife. Just remember, though, in the immortal words of Rudyard Kipling: "A woman is just a woman, but a cigar is a smoke.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MAN
turns.text: What does that mean?

turns.speaker: AUGGIE
turns.text: Damned if I know. But it has a nice ring to it, don't it?

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: Is your name Paul Benjamin?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What can I do for you?

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: I just want to know what your game is, mister, that's all.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: How the hell did you get into the building?

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: What do you mean, how'd I get in? I pushed the door and walked in. What do you think?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: The damn lock's broken again.  And so you just barge in on strangers, is that what you do? Is that your game?

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: I'm looking for my nephew,  Thomas.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Thomas? Who's Thomas?

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: Don't give me any of that. I know he's been here. You can't fool me, mister.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'm telling you. I don't know anyone named Thomas.

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: Thomas Cole. Thomas Jefferson Cole. My nephew.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You mean Rashid?

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: Rashid? Rashid! Is that what he told you his name was?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, whatever his name is, he's not here anymore. He left two days ago, and I haven't heard from him since.

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: And what was he doing here in the first place? That's what I want to know. What's a man like you messing around with a black boy like Thomas for? Are you some kind of pervert, or what?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Look, lady, that's enough. If you don't calm down. I'm going to throw you out. Do you hear me? Right now!

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: I just want to know where he is.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: As far as I know, he went back to his parents.

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: His parents? Is that what he told you? His parents?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: That's what he said. He told me he lived with his mother and father on East Seventy-fourth Street.

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: I always knew that boy had an imagination, but now he's gone and made up a whole new life for himself.  Do you mind if I sit down?  He's been living with me and his uncle Henry since he was a baby. And we don't live in Manhattan. We live in Boerum Hill. In the projects.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: He doesn't go to the Trinity School?

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: He goes to John Jay High School in Brooklyn.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And his parents?

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: His mother's dead, and he hasn't seen his father in twelve years.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I shouldn't have let him go.

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: Which brings me back to my original question. What was he doing here in the first place?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I was about to get run over by a car, and your nephew pulled me back. He saved my life.  I sensed he was in trouble, so I offered to put him up for a few days. Maybe I should have pressed him a little more, I don't know. I feel pretty stupid about it now.

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: He's in trouble, all right. But I don't have any idea what it is.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Do you want something to drink? A beer? A glass of water?

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: No thank you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Has anything happened lately? Anything unusual or unexpected?

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: Well, one thing I suppose, but I don't think it has anything to do with this.  A friend of mine called about two weeks ago and said she'd spotted Thomas's father working at some gas station outside of Peekskill.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And you told your nephew about it?

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: I figured he had a right to know.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: And nothing. Thomas looked at me straight in the eye and said, "I don't have a father. As far as I'm concerned, that son-of-a-bitch is dead."

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Those are pretty hostile words.

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: His father walked out on his mother a couple of months after he was born. Louisa was Henry's younger sister, and she and the baby moved in with us. Four or five years go by, and then one day Cyrus shows up out of the blue, tail between his legs, wanting to patch things up with Louisa. I thought Henry was going to tear Cyrus apart when he saw him walk through the door. They're both big men, those two, and if they ever started to tangle, you'd see some teeth jumping on the floor. I guarantee it ... So Cyrus persuaded Louisa to go out with him to talk things over in quiet. And the poor girl never came back.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You mean she just ran off with him and left her little boy behind?

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: Don't put words in my mouth. What I'm saying is she drove off in Cyrus's car and went to the Five-Spot Lounge with him for a drink. What I'm saying is that he imbibed too much in the way of alcohol and that when they finished their little talk three hours later and got back in the car, he was in no shape to drive. But he drove the car anyway, and before he could get her back to where she lived, the damn fool ran a red light and went straight into a truck. Louisa got thrown through the windshield and was killed. Cyrus lived, but he came out of it a cripple. His left arm was so mangled, the doctors had to cut it off. Small punishment for what he did, if you ask me.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Jesus.

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: Jesus had nothing to do with it. If He'd been involved. He would have seen to it that things worked out the opposite from what they did.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It can't have been easy on him. Walking around with that on his conscience all these years.

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: No, I don't suppose it has. He was broken up like nobody's business in that hospital when he found out Louisa was dead.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And he's never tried to get in touch with his son?

turns.speaker: AUNT EM
turns.text: Henry told Cyrus he'd kill him if he ever showed his face around our house again. When Henry makes a threat like that, people tend to take him seriously.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: You going to sit here all day?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I don't know. I haven't decided yet.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: Why don't you pick some other spot? It gives a man the creeps to be stared at all morning.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: It's a free country, isn't it? As long as I'm not trespassing on your property. I can stay here till kingdom come.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: Let me give you some useful information, son. There's two dollars and fifty-seven cents in that cash register over there  and considering all the time you've put in casing the joint so far, you won't make but about fifty cents an hour for all your pains. However you slice it, that's a losing proposition.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I'm not going to rob you, mister.  Do I look like a thief?

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: I don't know what you look like, boy. As far as I can tell, you sprouted up like a mushroom in this spot last night.  You live in this town -- or on your way from here to there?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Just passing through.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: Just passing through. A lonesome traveler with a knapsack on his back plops himself across from my garage to admire the view. There's other places to roam, kid, that's all I'm saying. You don't want to make a nuisance of yourself.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I'm working on a sketch. That old garage of yours is so rundown, it's kind of interesting.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: It's rundown, all right. But drawing a picture won't improve the way it looks.  Let's see what you did, Rembrandt.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: It'll cost you five bucks.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: Five bucks! You mean you're going to charge me five bucks just to look at it?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Once you look at it, you're going to want to buy it from me. That's guaranteed. And that's the price: five bucks. So if you're not willing to spring for it, you might as well not bother to look. It'll just tear you up inside and make you miserable.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: Son-of-a-bitch. You're some piece of work, aren't you?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I just tell it like it is, mister.  If I'm getting on your nerves, though, you might want to think about hiring me.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: Do you have eyes in your head, or are those brown things bulging out of your sockets just marbles? You've been sitting here all day, and how many cars have you seen drive up and ask for gas?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Not a one.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: Not a one. Not one customer all day. I bought this broken-down shit-hole of a place three weeks ago, and if business don't pick up soon, I'm going straight down the skids. What do I want to be hiring someone for? I can't even pay my own wages.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: It was just a thought.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: Yeah, well, do your thinking somewhere else, Michelangelo. I got work to do.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: I'll tell you what. You want to work. I'll give you a job. Nothing permanent, mind you, but that upstairs room over there  -- the one above the office -- is a hell of a mess. It looks like they've been throwing junk in there for twenty years, and it's time it got cleaned up.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: What's your offer?

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: Five bucks an hour. That's the going rate, isn't it?  It's a quarter past two now. My wife's picking me up at five-thirty, so that'll give you about three hours. If you can't finish today, you can do the rest tomorrow.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Is there a benefits package, or are you hiring me on a freelance basis?

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: Benefits?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: You know, health insurance, dental plan, paid vacation. It's not fun being exploited. Workers have to stand up for their rights.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: I'm afraid we'll be working on a strictly freelance basis.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Five dollars an hour?  I'll take it.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: The name is Cyrus Cole.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Paul. Paul Benjamin.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I don't mean to be nosy, but I was wondering what happened to your arm.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: An ugly piece of hardware, isn't it?  I'll tell you what happened to my arm.  I'll tell you what happened.  Twelve years ago, God looked down on me and said, "Cyrus, you're a bad, stupid, selfish man. First of all, I'm going to fill your body with spirits, and then I'm going to put you behind the wheel of a car, and then I'm going to make you crash that car and kill the woman who loves you. But you, Cyrus, I'm going to let you live, because living is a lot worse than death. And just so you don't forget what you did to that poor girl, I'm going to rip off your arm and replace it with a hook. If I wanted to, I could rip off both your arms and both your legs, but I'm going to be merciful and just take off your left arm. Every time you look at your hook, I want you to remember what a bad, stupid, selfish man you are. Let that be a lesson to you, Cyrus, a warning to mend your ways."

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: And have you mended them?

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: I don't know. I try. Every day I keep on trying, but it's no easy task for a man to change his nature.  I'm off the booze, though. Haven't had a drop in six years. And now I've got me a wife. Doreen. Best damned woman I've ever known.  And a little boy, too. Cyrus Junior.  So things have definitely improved since I got fitted with this hook. If I can just turn this goddamn garage around, I'll be in pretty good shape.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: You named the kid after yourself, huh?

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: That boy's one in a million. A real tiger.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: It's only temporary. On a freelance basis.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: And this one, in case you haven't guessed, is Junior.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Hi there, little brother.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: Say hi to Paul.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: That's funny. His name is the same as yours.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Well, you and Junior have the same name, too, don't you?

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: Yeah, but he's my son. Nothing strange about that. He's my own flesh and blood. But here you got the same name as this man here, and you're not even the same color.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: That's how we met. We're members of the International Same Name Club. Believe it or not, there are 846 Paul Benjamins in America. But only two in the New York metropolitan area. That's how Paul and I got to be such good friends. We're the only ones who show up at the meetings.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Thomas.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: Paul. Rashid. Thomas. Which one is it?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Thomas.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Thomas Cole. My name is Thomas Jefferson Cole.

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: Are you making fun of me? I won't be mocked. Do you hear me? I won't let no punk kid stand there and mock me!

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: I don't like this. I don't like it one bit.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Louisa Vail. Remember her, Cyrus?

turns.speaker: CYRUS
turns.text: You shut your mouth! You shut your mouth now!

turns.speaker: FELICITY
turns.text: Yeah? Who is it?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: It's me, honey. It's Mom.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: FELICITY
turns.text: Well what?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Aren't you going to say anything?

turns.speaker: FELICITY
turns.text: What do you want me to say?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I don't know. Hello, Mom. Hello, Dad. Something like that.

turns.speaker: FELICITY
turns.text: I don't got no daddy, you dig? I got born last week when some dog fucked you up the ass.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Be nice, sweetie. We're just here to help you.

turns.speaker: FELICITY
turns.text: Help? What the fuck do I need your help for? I've got a man, don't I? That's more than you can say for yourself, Hawkeye.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: You can do whatever you want with your own life. We're thinking of the baby, that's all. We want you to get yourself cleaned up for the baby. Before it's too late.

turns.speaker: FELICITY
turns.text: Baby? And what baby is that?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Your baby. The baby you're carrying around inside you.

turns.speaker: FELICITY
turns.text: Yeah, well, there ain't no baby in there now. You dig? There's nothing in there now.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: FELICITY
turns.text: An abortion, stupid.  I had an abortion the day before yesterday. So you don't have to bug me about that shit anymore.  Bye-bye, baby!

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: I'll tell you why they're not going anywhere.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Yeah? And why is that?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Management. Those guys are walking around with their heads up their asses.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Okay, joke about it. I don't give a shit.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Jesus, Tommy, it ain't science, you know. You got your good trades and your bad trades. That's how it works.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: They didn't have to do a thing, that's all I'm saying. The team was good, the best fucking team in baseball. But then they had to screw it up.  They traded their birthright for a mess of porridge.  A mess of porridge.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Sure. He's the guy who threw his cloak down over the puddle.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I used to smoke Raleigh cigarettes. They came with a free gift coupon in every pack.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Of course there's gonna be a war. You think they'd send five hundred thousand troops over there just to lie in the sun? I mean, there's plenty of beach, but not a hell of a lot of water. Half a million soldiers. It ain't no seaside holiday, you can bet on that.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I don't know, Tommy. You think anyone gives a rat's ass about Kuwait? I read something about the head sheik over there. He marries a different virgin every Friday and then divorces her on Monday. You think we want to have our kids dying for a guy like that?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Hey, Jimmy. You got the time?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You still have that watch Auggie gave you?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Tick-tock, tick-tock.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: So what's the time?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Twelve-eleven.  Twelve-twelve.  Twelve-twelve.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Watch out, man. You'll get yourself killed like that.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I can't believe I did that ... Christ. I'm walking around in a fog ...

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: No harm done. Everything's okay now.  I've got to be going.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No, wait. You can't just walk off.  You saved my life.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I just happened to be there.  The right place at the right time.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I owe you something.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: It's okay, mister. No big deal.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yes it is. It's a law of the universe. If I let you walk away, the moon will spin out of orbit ... pestilence will reign over the city for a hundred years.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Well, if you put it that way...

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You have to let me do something for you to put the scales in balance.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: That's all right. If I think of something, I'll send my butler over to tell you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Come on. At least let me buy you a cup of coffee.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I don't drink coffee.  On the other hand, since you insist, if you offered me a cold lemonade. I wouldn't say no.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Good. Lemonade it is.  I'm Paul.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Rashid. Rashid Cole.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Are you sure you don't want some food to go along with it? It might help to absorb some of that liquid. You don't want to slosh around too much when you stand up.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: That's okay. I've already had lunch.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You must eat lunch pretty early. It's only eleven o'clock.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I mean breakfast.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah, sure, and I bet you had lobster last night. Along with two bottles of champagne.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Just one bottle. I believe in moderation.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Look, kid, it's okay with me. You don't have to play games. If you want a hamburger or something, go ahead and order it.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Well, maybe just one. To be polite.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Cocktail hour is over. The young man would like to order a hamburger.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Mostly what.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You don't have to tell me if you don't want to, but I might be able to help.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: You don't know me from a hole in the wall.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: That's true. But I also owe you something, and I'm not sure that buying you a hamburger is going to do the job.  What is it? Family problems? Money problems?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Oh no. Momsie and Popsie have oodles.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And where do Momsie and Popsie live?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: East Seventy-fourth Street.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: In Manhattan?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Of course. Where else?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Then what are you doing in Park Slope? It's a little far from home, isn't it?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: That's where the what comes in.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: The what?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: The what.  I've kind of run away from home, you see.  It has nothing to do with my parents or money. I saw something I wasn't supposed to see, and for the time being it's best that I keep myself out of sight.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You can't be more specific than that?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Here and there. Around.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Uh-huh. One of those cozy bed and breakfast places, probably.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Yeah, that's right.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Except that there's no bed, is there? And no breakfast either.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: The material world is an illusion. It doesn't matter if they're there or not. The world is in my head.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: But your body is in the world, isn't it?  If someone offered you a place to stay, you wouldn't necessarily refuse, would you?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: People don't do that kind of thing. Not in New York.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'm not "people." I'm just me. And I do whatever I goddamn want to do. Got it?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Thanks, but I'll manage.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: In case you're wondering, I like women, not little boys. And I'm not offering you a long-term lease -- just a place to crash for a couple of nights.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I can take care of myself. Don't worry.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Suit yourself. But if you change your mind, here's the address.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I didn't expect to see you again.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Same here. But I had a long talk with my accountant this afternoon. You know, to see how a move like this would affect my tax picture, and he said it would be okay.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: That's it. Just the two rooms.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: This is the first house I've been in without a TV.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I used to have one, but it broke a couple of years ago and I never got around to replacing it.  I'd just as soon not have one anyway. I hate those damn things.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: But then you don't get to watch the ball games. You told me you were a Mets fan.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I listen on the radio. I can see the games just fine that way.  The world is in your head, remember?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Nice drawing. Did you do that?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: My father did. Believe it or not, that little baby is me.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Yeah, I can believe it.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's strange, though, isn't it? Looking at yourself before you knew who you were.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Is your father an artist?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No, he was a schoolteacher. But he liked to dabble.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: He's dead?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Twelve, thirteen years ago.  Actually, he died with his sketch pad open on his lap. Up in the Berkshires one weekend, drawing a picture of Mount Greylock.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Drawing's a good thing.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Is that what you do? Draw pictures?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Yeah, sometimes.  I like to dabble, too.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Time to wake up.  Hey, kid, time to wake up.  Rashid!  Up and out. I have to work in here. The slumber party is over.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: What time is it?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Eight-thirty.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Eight-thirty?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You'll find juice and eggs and milk in the refrigerator. Cereal in the cupboard. Coffee on the stove. Take whatever you want. But it's time for me to get started in here.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Jesus, do you make a lot of noise. Can't you see I'm trying to work?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I'm sorry. They just... they just slipped out of my hands.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: A little less clumsiness around here would be nice, don't you think?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I'm a teenager. All teenagers are clumsy. It's because we're still growing. We don't know where our bodies end and the world begins.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: The world is going to end pretty soon if you don't learn fast.  Look, why not make yourself useful? I'm just about out of smokes.  Go around the corner to the Brooklyn Cigar Company and buy me two tins of Schimmelpenninck Medias.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Twenty dollars is a lot of money. Are you sure you can trust me with it? I mean, aren't you afraid I might steal it?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: If you want to steal it, that's your business. At least I won't have you around here making noise.  It might be worth it.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I'm sorry. I'm really sorry... I was trying to reach for one of the books up there ...  And then, I don't know, the sky fell on top of me.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It just won't do, will it? I go two and a half years without being able to write a word, and then, when I finally get started on something, when it looks as though I might actually be coming to life again, you show up and start breaking everything in my house. It just won't do, will it?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I didn't ask to come here. You invited me, remember?  If you want me to leave, all you have to do is say so.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: How long have you been here?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Three nights.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And how long did I tell you you could stay?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Two or three nights.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It sounds like our time is up, doesn't it?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I'm sorry I messed up. You've been very kind to me ...  But all good things have to come to an end, right?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No hard feelings, okay? It's a small place, and I can't get my work done with you around.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: You don't have to apologize.  The coast is probably clear now anyway.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Are you going to be all right?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Absolutely. The world is my oyster.  Whatever that means.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Do you need some money? Some extra clothes?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Not a penny, not a stitch. I'm cool, man.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Take good care of yourself, okay?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: You too. And make sure the light is green before you cross the street.  Oh, by the way, I liked your book. I think you're a hell of a good writer.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Hey, it's you.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I wanted to give you this as a token of my appreciation.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Appreciation for what?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I don't know. For helping me out.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Where did you get that thing?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I bought it. Twenty-nine ninety-five on sale at Goldbaum's TV and Radio.  Well, that just about takes care of it, I guess. You'll be able to watch the ball games. You know, as a little break from your work.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Where the hell do you think you're going?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Business appointment. I'm seeing my broker at three o'clock.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Cut it out, will you? Just cut it out and come back here.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I don't have much time.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Close the door.  Sit down in that chair.  Now listen carefully. Your Aunt Em came here a couple of days ago. She was sick with worry, out of her mind. We had an interesting talk about you, Thomas. Do you understand what I'm saying? Your aunt thinks you're in trouble and so do I. Tell me about it, kid. I want to hear all about it right now.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: You don't really want to know.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I don't, huh? And what makes you such an authority on what I want or don't want?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Okay, okay.  It's all so stupid.  There's this guy, see. Charles Clemm. The Creeper, that's what people call him. The kind of guy you don't want to cross paths with.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I crossed paths with him. That's why I'm trying to stay clear of my neighborhood.  To make sure I don't run into him again.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: So that's the something you weren't supposed to see, huh?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I just happened to be walking by... All of a sudden, the Creeper and this other guy come running out of this check-cashing place with masks on their faces and guns in their hands... They just about ran smack into me. The Creeper recognized me, and I knew he knew I recognized him... If the guy from the check-cashing place hadn't rushed out then screaming bloody murder, he would have shot me. I'm telling you, the Creeper would have shot me right there on the sidewalk. But the noise distracted him, and when he turned around to see what was happening, I took off... One more second, and I would have been dead.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Why don't you go to the police?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: You're joking, right? I mean, that's your way of trying to be funny, right?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: If they put this Creeper in jail, then you'd be safe.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: The man has friends. And they're not likely to forgive me if I testify against him.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What makes you think you'll be any safer around here? It's only about a mile away from where you live.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: It might not be far, but it's another galaxy. Black is black and white is white, and never the twain shall meet.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It looks like they've met in this apartment.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: That's because we don't belong anywhere. You don't fit into your world, and I don't fit into mine. We're the outcasts of the universe.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Maybe. Or maybe it's the other people who don't belong.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Let's not get too idealistic.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Fair enough. We wouldn't want to get carried away, would we?  Now call your aunt Em and let her know you're alive.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Ah, coffee. Smells good.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: One sip of this stuff and your eyes will blast open.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: What time did you get to bed last night?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I don't know. Two or three. It was pretty late.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: You work too hard, you know that?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Once a story gets hold of you, it's hard to let go.  Besides, I'm making up for lost time.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Just so you don't overdo it. You don't want to die of sleep deprivation before you finish.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: If you don't sleep, you don't dream. If you don't dream, you don't have nightmares.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: That's logical. And if you don't sleep, you don't need a bed. Saves you money, too.  So what's this story you're working on, anyway?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: If I tell you, I might not be able to finish it.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Come on, just a little hint.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Okay, just a little hint. I can't tell you the story, but I'll tell you what gave me the idea for it.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: The inspiration.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah, right. The inspiration. It's a true story anyway, so I don't suppose it can hurt, can it?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: No way.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: All right. Listen carefully.  About twenty-five years ago, a young man went skiing alone in the Alps. There was an avalanche, the snow swallowed him up, and his body was never recovered.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: The end.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No, not the end. The beginning.  His son was just a little boy at the time, but the years passed, and when he grew up, he became a skier, too. One day last winter, he went out by himself for a run down the mountain. He gets halfway to the bottom and then stops to eat his lunch next to a big rock. Just as he's unwrapping his cheese sandwich, he looks down and sees a body frozen in the ice -- right there at his feet. He bends down to take a closer look, and suddenly he feels that he's looking into a mirror, that he's looking at himself. There he is -- dead -- and the body is perfectly intact, sealed away in a block of ice -- like someone preserved in suspended animation. He gets down on all fours, looks right into the dead man's face, and realizes that he's looking at his father.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Celebrate? What for?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: It's my birthday. I'm seventeen years old  as of forty-seven minutes ago, and I think I should celebrate having made it this far.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Hey, hey. Happy birthday. Why didn't you tell me?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I just did.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I mean earlier. We could have planned something.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Here we are.  Rembrandt's drawings. Edward Hopper. Van Gogh's letters.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Pick two or three. Now that the coffers are open, you might as well take advantage of me.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Uh, actually, I tend to shy away from that kind of thing.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Excuse me for asking, but you aren't married, are you?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Yes, an invitation. I apologize for springing it on you at the last minute, but Mr. Benjamin and I are attending a celebration tonight, and we would be most pleased if you chose to accompany us.  Isn't that right, Mr. Benjamin?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Absolutely. We would be honored.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's 1942, right? And he's caught in Leningrad during the siege. I'm talking about one of the worst moments in human history. Five hundred thousand people died in that one place, and there's Bakhtin, holed up in an apartment, expecting to be killed any day. He has plenty of tobacco, but no paper to roll it in. So he takes the pages of a manuscript he's been working on for ten years and tears them up to roll his cigarettes.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: His only copy?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: His only copy.  I mean, if you think you're going to die, what's more important, a good book or a good smoke? And so he huffed and he puffed, and little by little he smoked his book.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Nice try. You had me going for a second, but no ... no writer would ever do a thing like that.  Would he?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You don't believe me, huh?  Look, I'll show you. It's all in this book.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Is it yours?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Yeah, it might be.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Here, catch.
